content.label: A pretty good game, though the instructions take a bit to wade through...after giving it five or six games I got the hang of it.  Would recommend to the board game crowd as a well as those who like strategy video games.

title.label: Great game, even if it feels cheap

content.label: I love Elder Sign. The board game is excellent & I think the app is great, but my biggest problem lies with the fact that it often feels like this game cheats. Yes, poor choices often result in losses, and a good strategy will help, but I've managed to lose on "easy" cards despite having more than enough clue tokens & items to reasonably beat it. It feels like after a certain amount of successes, you will automatically fail on 1 or 2 adventures. On some of the harder cards, it feels like you need to sacrifice investigators & items before being able to pass it. The curator is arguably the most ridiculously adventure in the game. I've had to beat some cards with 4 Investigators, but that's the one card where I've had all 4, had a very well equipped Joe Diamond (with 5 clues aka 10 rerolls) and still lost! I don't know what kind of algorithm the game uses to determine successes & failures, but it feels as if FFG deliberately stacked the deck highly against the player. Considering that I have full control of my rolls in the Board game version & fail considerably less, it's hard not to feel like the game cheats. I still enjoy the app, but some days it feels like a trial in patience. It's why I typically end up playing the board game version instead. At least I can control my own dice roll. Either way, if you can get past the notion that the game cheats and are willing to deal with many losses before beating the harder AO's, this game is still a good way to kill some time, or play ES without having to set and clean up.

For starters, I own and play the board game frequently and, unlike other games, namely Neuroshima Hex, this game is better on the table than a screen. The user interface is often confusing. Misclicks happen often with no way to undo them. There are too many cinematic transitions that arbitrarily lengthen game time. There's a transistion in between basically anything that could possibly happen and anything after that. It's borderline ridiculous. The game is slightly different as in the board game you don't auto lose when the doom track fills up. Also, I really do feel this is harder than the board game. I only lose on the table about 25% of the time over many playthroughs both solo and teaching new people. I've beaten this once. The discrepancy is too big for me to assume it's just bad luck. If you don't want the physical version (which isn't that expensive) and just need to play this, it's serviceable. But it's not for me.

title.label: Plays fairly quickly. A decent challenge.

content.label: I've never played the board game, but might pick it up now that I've played a few games. Played four games since downloading yesterday. Lost two, won two. One was the hardest one. Both wins were within a turn of losing. I'll likely buy the expansions if they go on sale. There is no credence to the rigged roll complaints at all. Most symbols have only a 1:6 chance of coming up on any glyph conjure (roll). If you need multiples of those glyphs, your unlikely to statistically get them unless you're using the abilities of the investigators to lock glyphs or re-roll a few times. Just read/watch the help menu. Attempt to play (and lose) a scenario and you'll have a pretty good sense of the strategy of the game. Not as tight as some other cooperative games I've played, but a decent level of challenge not regretting picking it up.
Great game and if you played the actual game. You'll actually know that you need to make use of everything that can help you get those trophies. Also the game is suppose to be hard.
Hoping for more expansions
It's rigged. I have played the easy setting 5 times and died each Time. Don't wast you time like me.
Hours and hours of fun.  Compared to most games this is no ripoff!

title.label: Great Game that’s hampered by bad randomization

content.label: ES looks great, plays well enough, but is held back by some suspicious randomization. I sat down and played this game for about five hours and at first thought it was difficult, but then realized that I’d often fail to pull up markers that I needed, even with six markers I’d not get the one that I needed. It just feels a bit “off."

Played the card game and went to this. Love both immensely. There is definitely some strategic action needed when attempting adventures. If the a character ill equipped to perform the task tries they most likely fail. Sometimes, it's even difficult to win when you have everything necessary. Good game and on the edge of your seat thriller.

title.label: I have had no problems - GREAT GAME

content.label:
Going through these reviews, I have to wonder if the tutorial isn't quite clear enough. There are a few nuances, but if you can make some tough decisions, the game is certainly beatable. I beat all four of the starting Old Ones (Yig and Hastur on my first try), and I'm on to Cthulhu.

It's a dice game where you pick characters based on their perks, and beat challenges while accruing loot and sealing away the "big bad". Meanwhile, the "big bad" is throwing in monsters to make the challenges more difficult, and opening portals to other worlds. Some challenges need to be nipped in the bud before things get out of hand (especially the ones with "midnight effects"), and it's YOUR job to manage the risk, bonuses, and livelihood of your party. You also get "trophy points" for beating these challenges, which can be used at the entrance to buy more bonuese, or recover health. It certainly not easy, but the game throws you bone often enough.

With all due respect, seeing these other reviews saying "the dice are rigged" is beyond disappointing - the tutorial tells you what the odds on the dice (or "glyphs", whatever) are! If the odds are something other than what that tutorial claims, I'd be shocked. I've had plenty of fun, and challenges, with no issues.

title.label: Buy a physical copy of the card game instead.

content.label: This version of the game is too difficult. I'm playing on the easiest setting and I am unable to progress through the adventures while my team drops like flies.

title.label: Bad dice rolling ruins a good game

content.label: The dice rolls are just straight up unfair for large parts of the game. Please fix.

Nice attempt to bring the enjoyable (and winnable) board game to the mobile world. Sadly, the game is rigged against the player. There is no way of winning any scenario of this game. The dice (AI) is against you 110%. After dozens of playthroughs I've yet to win even ONCE. Not worthy of the same name as the board game. Save your money.

I didn't think it was true at first, but the dice do seem unbalanced, and get worse the more players you add. It makes an otherwise great game into a frustrating exercise. It's a lot more fun to just play the board game on your own than this.

I have played this board game, and it's awesome. When I read the reviews for this app, I assumed the people complaining about the rolls maybe just weren't familiar with the difficulty level of FF games. However, after playing a few games I can confirm that the dice rolls are way too unbalanced. I have yet to win a game because the dice rolls are not chance, they are rolling straight up against you. Until that is fixed I'm afraid I can only give this 3 stars, if they fix it this would be an amazing translation from a great board game to a great app.

The dice are rolled. It is so silly not to have straight up statistical rolling. I assume they want tension - but it just makes it irritating ^10.

Fix please

I have played 4 games (all finished in a losses) and only succeeded in a total of 3 mission. The rolls are just unrealistic bordering on unbelievable. Until I get an update I will probably stop playing because it's no fun to just keep getting beat down. Challenge is one thing but this is ridiculous.

This game is well worth the price. Using the characters' unique abilities intelligently is about the only way to win.

That said, the dice rolls are often BS, which is somewhat frustrating. There's bad luck, and then there's bad balancing. This occasionally falls into the latter category. Please fix!

I'd love to see Fantasy Flight adapt more games soon.
this game has very little to no strategy, everything is dependent on rolling the right signs. Winning the "easy" level is impossible and I do not understand most of the special items.

title.label: As fun as the dice game

content.label: I'm a huge fan of fantasy flight and there arkham horror series of games and I love this app it's great when I can get a game group together it is a fun option
Simple but immersive game into the sublime world of Lovecraft.  Gameplay mechanics are very intricate and the 30 minute sessions are never the same.
Simple but immersive game into the sublime world of Lovecraft.  Gameplay mechanics are very intricate and the 30 minute sessions are never the same.
Must buy for fans of the Board Game and of strategy/and or dice board gamers in general

title.label: Best Board Game to Application I have ever played.

content.label:
I recently played the ES board game and fell in love with it. I found out today from my best friend (the one who introduced the board game to me) that there was a mobile app for it.

After my first game on the app, I only saw a few slight differences. You don't have full access to everything the board game has, mainly it's missing Blessings/Curses and Allies. Makes it more challenging. 

In app purchases are cheap, and you get a ton of stuff. I will definitely be doing those purchases in the future. 

All in all this app in my opinion is worth the $3.00 for the base. (Add $9.00 to get the other 3 in app expansions).
Wish there were more gods with the base game. Excellent port of the board game otherwise.

title.label: Plays just like the dice game but with only 1 player

content.label: Fun.

title.label: Superb Translation of the Tabletop Experience

content.label: With gorgeous art, an intuitive interface, and atmospheric audio, this app captures the soul of one of my favorite cooperative tabletop games.  Video tutorials and an excellent in-game help guide allow new players to quickly delve into the dark world of Elder Sign, and those familiar with the tabletop version will feel right at home with their old pals, the Ancient Ones.  Play solo - leading your team of four personally selected investigators, each with their own unique skills, or play locally with friends - passing your mobile device as you work collectively to drive back the horrors seeping into our world and seal away the darkness forever under the power of the Elder Sign.

The game is completely arbitrary there's little to no strategy involved and it's 100% based on luck. In several rounds I lost the game trying to roll 6 investigation and 2 scrolls. 4 chars could not roll those in so many turns I lost the game on that one "adventure". TBH after playing this there's no way I would ever buy elder sign. Beautiful game but God awful gameplay. 2 tentacles way down.

Update 2: Store now defunct. Uninstalled for while, then reinstalled, and now I can no longer access the DLC I already paid for.

Update: Still no multiplayer...wow.

Wasn't sure it would be worth the money, but I ended buying both expansions -- it's that good. However, a $10 investment demands more features, the first being asynchronous multiplayer. The board game is for 1-8 players, and there's simply no reason this digital version should be single-player only. It also needs Game Center support. You get a score at the end of the game, why no online leaderboard? Lastly, for a game this size (and price), iCloud saving should be a gimme. 

Give me those things, and this game will be right on the money (and 5-stars).

For those looking for a great board game experience on their phone or iPad, look no further.  This is a fantastic digital recreation of one of the best card games out there.  Several other reviews touched on the main points that make the game great so I will skip those to address things that may help people on the fence decide.  First off this game is great for multiplayer!  Simply pick your investigators and pass the device when your turn is up.  It works great in this capacity.  Secondly this game is a lot of strategy requiring a bit of luck.  What I mean by this is you have to play to your investigator's strengths and abilities.  You can't just send them off to any adventure and expect to win.  Set yourself up for success by combining your abilities with your current items to tackle each adventure.  Thirdly, you will die.  A lot.  Sometimes the stars just don't align properly, the dice fall short, and you fail even when you set yourself up for success.  This is the nature of board games and in this board game the deck is stacked against you.  Remember it's you vs the game, not the other players.

Edit:  the expansions are totally worth the money.  They take the board game beyond what is currently available.

While pretty, and well made, there isn't much of a chance for newbies. 
If you want to learn to play, this isn't a good option, the easiest option this game gives is normal, which honestly isn't that easy. 

Adding in 2 easy monsters would make this better, and help me convince friends to actually play the board game.

title.label: Weirdly enthralling, but not for everyone

content.label:
I wish Omens kept statistics so I could tell you how many times it's destroyed me. Having started dozens of games, I think I've won three or four times, tops. That's the kind of game Elder Sign is: it does take prisoners, but it shoves them raving in an asylum cell, never to see the sun again.

Elder Sign has almost inconceivably high production values. The amount, variety and quality of the artwork is incredible. The game looks and sounds fantastic, and the little Mythos one-liners on tasks help focus the mood. The later DLC campaigns even allow for multiple outcomes to the game (or so I hear; I've never finished most if them). For a late-night haunted museum simulator, it's top tier.

Omens' one problem is that in many ways it...isn't a game. Conflict resolution is managed by rolling a handful of dice and matching them against a series of ordered requirements, thus completing tasks. Some active tasks can have consequences, inflicting punishments at midnight or even locking part of your hand of dice. While characters do have special abilities, most of your decisions in the game are the decision to use or save various items that increase the number of dice you have to roll or allow rerolls. As a gameplay interaction mechanic, it's weak, and you'll constantly feel at the mercy of the brutal dice gods as near-impossible tasks prove...near impossible and that beast probability destroys you even on simple tasks. The randomness can be boring at best and hugely frustrating at worst. The question of whether Omens can even count as a "game" when randomness is the most important factor is debatable, and some people will doubtless not be able to hold their attention on the task.

In spite of that, Elder Sign is weirdly enthralling. Failure is a tradition of Cthulhu Mythos stories, so it's not too surprising when most forays end in the end of the world. There's something very right about a certain amount of downer in a Mythos game, and the art and sense of urgency do a lot to keep the player involved even when he realistically has very little agency. Yeah, Bluetooth multiplayer wouldn't go amiss, but it's hard to know how badly such a protracted game requires online play. All in all, if you're a Mythos fan and don't mind frequent and sometimes highly random failure, you should drop a few dollars on Omens, and maybe pick up some of the weirder expansions, too. You've got nothing to lose but your mind.

I was planning to buy the board game but glad I didn't. This game just frustrate you to no end. Even when trying to use strategy, which there is not much, I still end up losing. I have only won one time. I know your thinking he's probably played it wrong. I have put over 30 hours and your chance is low on getting any of the symbol on the dice. The artwork is great but I'm glad that I didn't get the board game. Try small worlds for the iPad or ticket to ride.

I love this game. I would love to be able to play this with my husband as a team. Are there any plans to make an online version of this available to play with friends? My hubby and I love the board game elder sign and the app. The app is awesome! But we would love to be able to play the game together.

title.label: A Beautiful, extremely hard game. Random roll doesn't seem random

content.label: Like all fantasy flight games, it's well thought out and well made. For Cthulhu fans it's a must have. My gripe is that it's frustratingly hard. I'm not talking about having poor strategy, I'm talking about the glyph roll. The real game is a lot easier bc no one rolls dice this bad in real life. If you're up, you can guarantee that the conjuring roll will fail you. It almost feels like its not random and rather out to get you. Other than that, it's a very nice game to play when you're not at home playing the real game.
Excellent translation of the board game. Well made, awesome sound and music, and a good challenge.

This game is a random dice rollong slot machine. Only a slot machine will pay out eventually, in this game you just die! Seriously, random images pop up and you match them to the job, that is it! I want a refund.

Update 2.: It's been years since the game came out, and FFG still wasn't able to add iCloud support, Game Center integration, and still charges extra for the iPad version when almost all other apps are universal. Well, you won't see any more money from me...

Update: The game is still fun but now I see some issues. Hence the review update. First, no iCloud support (or any other online storing function). Not cool FFG! Also, if I want to play it on my iPad I have to buy it again (which I refuse to do so). Don't be greedy FFG and make this a universal app! Lastly, this new monster appearance mechanic is plain ugly. What was wrong with the old one?! 

Original: This is simply a great game, requiring a lot of strategy (even though throwing dice is random, you can cleverly tip the scale to your favor with skills, items, and some general thinking). It is fun, and looks really nice. What else would you need? Also, with this latest Cthulhu expansion the challenge went up considerably, which is a welcome addition as the base game was kind of easy. I cannot recommend Elder Sign enough.

Loads of fun and suspense. Great art, great gameplay and suspense. The downside is that I needed to watch some online videos in order to learn the game. What is the shoe icon? Dunno go online and find out. How many skulls is on the green dice? Is the it a 6 sided or 8 sided dice in the board game. Dunno go online to find out. Some of the fundamentals of the game depend in knowing which mission is right for the character or how risky is that mission, do I need power ups? All these questions are not answered in game. I wish the board game instruction book was in the app as a PDF. 4 stars due to lack of instructions.

I've never played the tabletop version of this, but I've played plenty of dice-based games (including Arkham Horror and plenty of Fantasy Flight titles) and I've never seen rolls go this poorly. I can practically predict my rolls: exactly what I don't need. Or one short of success. 

It's a sad truth that a lot video "board" games ramp up difficulty by making you less lucky, but I've never been as frustrated with a game as I am with this one. I tried a game tonight and the random generator created a board with red/yellow glyphs locked, both in places where it's next to impossible to succeed without those glyphs. I gave it a shot and - surprise - fell one short (no wiggle room) or wasn't even close... with all four of my investigators and a couple of Clues. 

Stacked games aren't fun. I hope something gets tweaked. Until then, I'm deleting this and freeing precious space on my phone for games that work.

1 word, awesome.
The best translation of a boardgame on iOS, art and animations are top notch, musical score is creepy, UI is perfect. The game? Download it now and see what you're missing 😃
Perfect for playing on the go, this digital version is even better than the original and absolutely stands on its own even if you don't normally enjoy board games. Both versions, iphone and ipad, are worth having, guess it's one of the very few games that shines on both platforms.
Always challenging, never frustrating. It's survival horror with turns.
Gets bigger with every update, love that they're always putting new content.
The only thing missing are online leaderboards!
Very fun board game, yeah the game can be random and frustrating but speaking as a big mythos fan, I think it just adds to the fun.

Well made and fun to play, but be warned! You pay all that money and they only give you a 3 bosses and a subset of adventures. The rest are in-app purchases. In my opinion in-app purchases should be bonuses etc., not the originally implied content. 

If you're going to spend that much just go get the real game. At least then you won't get short changed.

This game is great for fans of the Elder Signs dice game and any dice game in general.

But you must remember -- it is a dice game! You will find yourself frustrated OFTEN, but that's the nature of the game, and it makes it all the more rewarding when you do win. Plus, careful planning goes a long way.

That said, a really fun game, and I can't gush enough about the beautiful Lovecraft-inspired artwork.

The DLC is a bit expensive, but with so much love put into the artwork, it's easy to understand why. For fans of Lovecraft and dice games, this one's a must!

Its really great game but it highly depends on the luck!! And midnight is coming sooooo fast! There is no time to buy items cuz its too busy to close the potal and beat the monsters. Also sometimes midnight penalty place opens at THE MIDNIGHT!! then i cant do anything for it.

I purchased this and it's two expansions.  I love the graphics, audio and the game play however the game even if played with the most logical decision making to increase your chances of winning is done, the odds of winning is low because too many penalty monsters are dealt out at the end of most rounds.  One round my players were penalized with 8 monsters.  Also the special skills players are granted do not consistently work - needs fixing.  I have beaten the first two monsters but the last 3 I have not come close.  The twist on the adventure to Alaska is fun but also pretty impossible to win.  If you don't mind losing frequently and just love playing than I recommend this package.  FYI - all three games takes up a lot of memory as far as apps go.

title.label: Spot on to the board game

content.label: If you are familiar to the board game, this app is awesome and follows the board game to a T. My only complaints are the expansions are expensive (Same $ as original app) and the supposedly random dice seem quite unforgiving. Otherwise I'd highly suggest buying this game. I do believe it should have a walkthrough tutorial for those unfamiliar with this game.

title.label: Cthulhu Vs. The Gods of RNG

content.label:
Personally, I would go with Cthulhu over a random number generator (RNG) any day. Cthulhu is at least less fickle.

It's a beautiful game and has a great story with it, but the game mechanic is based completely on a random number generator (RNG). So strategy and careful planning are useless as everything is a roll of the die.

So you can complete several tough adventures in a row, all because the dice roll just the way you needed them to do. Only to fail on a simple one, because the dice failed to give the one thing that you really needed.

And once you start to fail adventures you tend to continue to fail. When you complete an adventure you can get items that allow you to modify die rolls, get more dice to roll, heal and so on. But each item is discarded once used, so losing an adventure means you don't get to replace any used items. And so you get weaker. A character can take a turn to heal or buy a new item, but taking a turn to do so is gamble as you can only do one thing. And the longer the game continues the harder the adventures can get. So it's easy to find yourself in an unwinable situation.

Unless, of course, you get really lucky on the dice rolls. Just ignore that fact that relying on a roll of the dice got you into this situation.
Still, more fun than a tentacle massage from the great one himself
